questions.question: She is interested  ………………………. to cook.
questions.description: The adjective interested is followed by in + noun/-ing form.

questions.question: She didn’t look happy ………………………….. me.
questions.description: The adjective happy is followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: That car is new, …………………………?
questions.description: We use a negative tag after an affirmative statement.

questions.question: It was …………………………… that I could hardly work.
questions.description: The structure is so + adjective/adverb + a/an + noun.

questions.question: They were …………………………… injured in the accident.
questions.description: Deadly is an adjective and it means fatal. The adverb for this meaning is fatally.

questions.question: I very much enjoy …………………………….
questions.description: The verb enjoy can be followed by a noun/pronoun/-ing form. It cannot be followed by an infinitive.

questions.question: He would never ……………………………… if he hadn’t changed jobs.
questions.description: The sentence is in the type three conditional. Here we use a past perfect in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the result clause.

questions.question: I don’t trust god men. I never have, and I ……………………………..
When I was ………………………….. I was working.
questions.description: The structure is/am/are etc. + … age is used without a preposition.

questions.question: Alice isn’t here today. Mary isn’t here ………………………………
questions.description: After mentioning a negative idea or fact, we can add another negative point by using not … either.

questions.question: He often comes and …………………………… the evening with us.
We didn’t have ……………………………. trouble going through the customs.
questions.description: Any suggests an indefinite quantity or number. It is often used in questions and negative clauses.
